name: Objexj
tagline: Regular expressions for arbitrary Java objects.
body: # `objexj` ## Regular Expressions for Java Objects ### January 16, 2012 ### ljnelson@gmail.com `objexj` is a small project that provides the ability to match *input* (a `List` of items) against an *expression*. That of course is what regular expressions are all about. The difference here is that you can use any Java `Object` you want, not just characters in a string. The syntax hews close to Perl-compatible regular expressions, with a few modifications. The underlying machinery is heavily inspired by [Russ Cox][1]'s excellent paper entitled [Regular Expression Matching: the Virtual Machine Approach][2]. This project is in heavy development. ### Sample Code @Test public void testLastException() throws IOException { final String sourceCode = "^java.lang.Exception*/(java.lang.Exception(message == \"third\"))$"; final Pattern pattern = Pattern.compile(sourceCode); assertNotNull(pattern); final List input = new ArrayList(); input.add(new IllegalStateException("first")); input.add(new IllegalArgumentException("second")); final Exception third = new RuntimeException("third"); input.add(third); final Matcher matcher = pattern.matcher(input); assertNotNull(matcher); assertEquals(2, matcher.groupCount()); final List group1 = matcher.group(1); assertNotNull(group1); assertEquals(1, group1.size()); final Exception group1Exception = group1.get(0); assertSame(third, group1Exception); } [1]: https://plus.google.com/116810148281701144465/posts [2]: http://swtch.com/~rsc/regexp/regexp2.html
